Nonetheless, improved gunpowder artillery played a part in the [[Tudor conquest of Ireland|reconquest of Ireland]] in the 1530s, where the successful English siege of [[Maynooth Castle]] in 1530 demonstrated the power of the new siege guns.<ref name="McNeill, p.228"/> There were still relatively few guns in Ireland however and, during the [[Nine Years' War (Ireland)|Nine Years' War]] at the end of the century, the Irish were proved relatively unskilled in siege warfare with artillery used mainly by the English.<ref>Lenihan, p.352.</ref> In both Ireland and Scotland the challenge was how to transport artillery pieces to castle sieges; the poor state of Scottish roads required expensive trains of pack horses, which only the king could afford, and in Ireland the river network had to be frequently used to transport the weapons inland.<ref>Lenihan, p.352; Reid, p.32.</ref> In these circumstances older castles could frequently remain viable defensive features, although the [[siege of Cahir Castle]] in 1599 and the attack on [[Dunyvaig Castle]] on Islay in 1614 proved that if artillery could be brought to bear, previously impregnable castle walls might fall relatively quickly.<ref>McNeill, p.228; Stell, p.283.</ref>
==17th century==
===Wars of the Three Kingdoms=== [[Image:Bolsover Castle 17th century.jpg|thumb|[[Bolsover Castle]] in England, following its redesign at the beginning of the 17th century]] {{main|Wars of the Three Kingdoms}}
In 1603 [[James VI of Scotland]] inherited the crown of England, bringing a period of peace between the two countries. The royal court left for London and, as a result – with the exceptions of occasional visits, building work on royal castles north of the border largely ceased.<ref>Dunnar, p.vii; Glendinning, MacInnes and MacKechnie, p.38.</ref> Investment in English castles, especially royal castles, declined dramatically. James sold off many royal castles in England to property developers, including [[York Castle|York]] and [[Southampton Castle]].<ref>Twyford, p.44; Butler, p.20; Emery (2006), p.292.</ref> A royal inspection in 1609 highlighted that the Edwardian castles of North Wales, including [[Conwy Castle|Conwy]], [[Beaumaris Castle|Beaumaris]] and [[Caernarfon Castle|Caernarfon]] were "[u]tterlie decayed".;<ref>Brown (1962), p.197.</ref> a subsequent inspection of various English counties in 1635 found a similar picture: [[Lincoln Castle|Lincoln]], [[Kendal Castle|Kendal]], York, [[Nottingham Castle|Nottingham]], [[Bristol Castle|Bristol]], [[Queenborough Castle|Queenborough]], [[Southampton Castle|Southampton]] and [[Rochester Castle|Rochester]] were amongst those in a state of dilapidation.<ref>Bull, p.82.</ref> In 1642 one pamphlet described many English castles as "muche decayed" and as requiring "much provision" for "warlike defence".<ref>Bull, pp.82–3.</ref> Those maintained as private homes; such as [[Arundel Castle|Arundel]], [[Berkeley Castle|Berkeley]], [[Carlisle Castle|Carlisle]] and [[Winchester Castle|Winchester]] were in much better condition, but not necessarily defendable in a conflict; while some such as [[Bolsover Castle|Bolsover]] were redesigned as more modern dwellings in a [[Palladian architecture|Palladian]] style.<ref>Bull, p.82; Gomme and Maguire, pp.69–72.</ref> A handful of coastal forts and castles, amongst them [[Dover Castle]], remained in good military condition with adequate defences.<ref>Harrington (2003), pp.11–2.</ref>
In 1642 the [[English Civil War]] broke out, initially between supporters of [[Roundheads|Parliament]] and the [[Cavaliers|Royalist]] supporters of [[Charles I of England|Charles I]]. The war expanded to include Ireland and Scotland, and dragged on into three separate conflicts in England itself. The war was the first prolonged conflict in Britain to involve the use of artillery and gunpowder.<ref name="Harrington 2003, p.4">Harrington (2003), p.4.</ref> English castles were used for various purposes during the conflict. [[York Castle]] formed a key part of the city defences, with a military governor; rural castles such as [[Goodrich Castle|Goodrich]] could be used a bases for raiding and for control of the surrounding countryside; larger castles, such as [[Windsor Castle|Windsor]], became used for holding prisoners of war or as military headquarters.<ref>Timbs and Gunn, p.170; Musty, p. 4.; Rowse, p.84.</ref> During the war castles were frequently brought back into fresh use: existing defences would be renovated, while walls would be "[[Contramure|countermured]]", or backed by earth, in order to protect from cannons.<ref>Bull, p.86.</ref> Towers and keeps were filled with earth to make gun platforms, such as at [[Carlisle Castle|Carlisle]] and [[Oxford Castle]].<ref>Bull, p.86; [http://thehumanjourney.net/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=507&Itemid=40 Oxford Archaeology], accessed 12 September 2010.</ref> New earth bastions could be added to existing designs, such as at [[Cambridge Castle|Cambridge]] and [[Carew Castle]] and at the otherwise unfortified [[Basing House]] the surrounding Norman [[ringwork]] was brought back into commission.<ref>Bull, p.86; Lowry, p.24; Creighton and Higham, p.62.</ref> The costs could be considerable, with the work at [[Skipton Castle]] coming to over £1000.<ref>Bull, p.95.</ref>
[[Image:Roaring Meg mortar.JPG|thumb|left|"[[Roaring Meg (cannon)|Roaring Meg]]", a surviving example of a civil-war [[Mortar (weapon)|mortar]]]] Sieges became a prominent part of the war with over 300 occurring during the period, many of them involving castles.<ref name="Harrington 2003, p.4"/> Indeed, as Robert Liddiard suggests, the "military role of some castles in the seventeenth century is out of all proportion to their medieval histories".<ref>Liddiard (2005), p.95.</ref> Artillery formed an essential part of these sieges, with the "characteristic military action" according to military historian Stephen Bull, being "an attack on a fortified strongpoint" supported by artillery.<ref>Bull, p.xxii; Hutton and Reeves, cited Lenihan, p.352.</ref>{{refn|Historian Stephen Bull has highlighted that earlier histories of the [[English Civil War]] underplayed the importance of artillery, focusing more on the pitched battles fought in the conflict; recent academic work has captured the significance and effectiveness of artillery in the conflict.<ref name=Bullpxxii>Bull, p.xxii.</ref>|group="nb"}} The ratio of artillery pieces to defenders varied considerably in sieges, but in all cases there were more guns than in previous conflicts; up to one artillery piece for every nine defenders was not unknown in extreme cases, such as near [[Pendennis Castle]].<ref name=Bullpxxii/> The growth in the number and size of siege artillery favoured those who had the resources to purchase and deploy these weapons.<ref>Lenihan, p.351.</ref> Artillery had improved by the 1640s but was still not always decisive, as the lighter cannon of the period found it hard to penetrate earth and timber bulwarks and defences – demonstrated in the siege of [[Corfe Castle|Corfe]].<ref>Lowry, p.24; Toy (1975), p.231; Harrington (2003), p.5.</ref> [[Mortar (weapon)|Mortar]]s, able to lob fire over the taller walls, proved particularly effective against castles – in particular those more compact ones with smaller courtyards and open areas, such as at [[Stirling Castle]].<ref>Bull, p.107; Duffy, p.159.</ref>
The heavy artillery introduced in England eventually spread to the rest of the British Isles. Although up to a thousand Irish soldiers who had served in Europe returned during the war, bringing with them experience of siege warfare from the [[Thirty Years' War]] in Europe, it was the arrival of [[Oliver Cromwell]]'s train of siege guns in 1649 that transformed the conflict, and the fate of local castles.<ref>McNeill, p.228; Lenihan, p.353.</ref> None of the Irish castles could withstand these Parliamentary weapons and most quickly surrendered.<ref name="McNeill, p.228"/> In 1650 Cromwell invaded Scotland and again his heavily artillery proved decisive.<ref>Tabraham and Grove, p.15.</ref>
===The Restoration=== [[Image:Corfe Castke 57.JPG|thumb|The ruined walls of [[Corfe Castle]] in England, [[slighting|slight]]ed after the [[English Civil War]]]] The [[English Civil War]] resulted in Parliament issuing orders to [[slighting|slight]] or damage many castles, particularly in prominent royal regions. This was particularly in the period of 1646 to 1651, with a peak in 1647.<ref>Rakoczy (2007), pp.46–47</ref> Around 150 fortifications were slighted in this period, including 38 town walls and a great many castles.<ref>Coulson (2003), pp.31–32.</ref> Slighting was quite expensive and took some considerable effort to carry out, so damage was usually done in the most cost-effective fashion with only selected walls being destroyed.<ref>Bull, p.134.</ref> In some cases the damage was almost total, such as [[Pontefract Castle]] which had been involved in three major sieges and in this case at the request of the townsfolk who wished to avoid further conflict.<ref name=Hull75>Hull (2009), p.75.</ref>
By the time that [[Charles II of England|Charles II]] was [[Restoration (England)|restored to the throne]] in 1660, the major palace-fortresses in England that had survived slighting were typically in a poor state. As historian Simon Thurley has described, the shifting "functional requirements, patterns of movement, modes of transport, aesthetic taste and standards of comfort" amongst royal circles were also changing the qualities being sought in a successful castle.<ref>Thurley, p.214</ref> [[Palladian architecture]] was growing in popularity, which sat awkwardly with the typical design of a medieval castle.<ref>ref needed.</ref> Furthermore, the fashionable French court etiquette at the time required a substantial number of [[Enfilade (architecture)|enfilade]]d rooms, in order to satisfy court protocol, and it was impractical to fit these rooms into many older buildings.<ref>Brindle and Kerr, p.50.</ref> A shortage of funds curtailed Charles II's attempts to remodel his remaining castles and the redesign of [[Windsor Castle|Windsor]] was the only one to be fully completed in the Restoration years.<ref>Nicolson, pp.128–9; Rowse, p.95.</ref>
Many castles still retained a defensive role. Castles in England, such as [[Chepstow Castle|Chepstow]] and [[York Castle]], were repaired and garrisoned by the king.<ref>Clarke, p.261; Turner (2006), p.24.</ref> As military technologies progressed the costs of upgrading older castles could be prohibitive – the estimated £30,000 required for the potential conversion of York in 1682, approximately £4,050,000 in 2009 terms, gives a scale of the potential costs.<ref>Butler, p.20.</ref><ref name="Measuring Worth">Financial comparison based on RPI; using the [http://www.measuringworth.com/index.php Measuring Worth] website. Accessed 15 March 2011.</ref> Castles played a minimal role in the [[Glorious Revolution]] of 1688, although some fortifications such as [[Dover Castle]] were attacked by mobs unhappy with the religious beliefs of their Catholic governors, and the sieges of [[King John's Castle (Limerick)|King John's Castle]] in [[Limerick]] formed part of the endgame to the war in Ireland.<ref>Hayton, pp.28–9; Williams (1984), p.254.</ref> In the north of Britain security problems persisted in Scotland. Cromwellian forces had built a number of new modern forts and barracks, but the royal castles of [[Edinburgh Castle|Edinburgh]], [[Dumbarton Castle|Dumbarton]] and Stirling, along with [[Dunstaffnage Castle|Dunstaffnage]], [[Dunollie Castle|Dunollie]] and [[Huntingtower Castle|Ruthven Castle]], also continued in use as practical fortifications.<ref>Whyte and Whyte, p.76; Tabraham and Grove, p.18.</ref> Tower houses were being built up until the 1640s; after the Restoration the fortified tower house fell out of fashion, but the weak state of the Scottish economy was such that while many larger properties were simply abandoned, the more modest castles continued to be used and adapted as houses, rather than rebuilt.<ref>Whyte and Whyte, p.77; Reid, p.57.</ref> In Ireland tower houses and castles remained in use until after the Glorious Revolution, when events led to a dramatic shift in land ownership and a boom in the building of Palladian country houses; in many cases using timbers stripped from the older, abandoned generation of castles and tower houses.<ref>McNeill, p.229.</ref>
==18th century==
===Military and governmental use=== [[Image:Carlisle Castle 03.jpg|thumb|[[Carlisle Castle]] in England, modernised in the 18th century to defend against [[Jacobitism|Jacobite]] invasion]] Some castles in Britain and Ireland continued to have modest military utility into the 18th century. Up until 1745 a sequence of [[Jacobite Risings|Jacobite risings]] threatened the Crown in Scotland, culminating in the [[Jacobite Rising of 1745|rebellion in 1745]].<ref>Whyte and Whyte, p.76.</ref> Various royal castles were maintained during the period either as part of the English border defences, like [[Carlisle Castle|Carlisle]], or forming part of the internal security measures in Scotland itself, like [[Stirling Castle]].<ref>Lowry, pp.37, 45.</ref> Stirling was able to withstand the Jacobite attack in 1745, although Carlisle was taken; the siege of [[Blair Castle]], at the end of the rebellion in 1746, was the final castle siege to occur in the British Isles.<ref>Lowry pp.37, 45; Reid, p.7.</ref> In the aftermath of the conflict [[Corgarff Castle|Corgaff]] and many others castles were used as barracks for the forces sent to garrison [[Scottish Highlands|the Highlands]].<ref>Reid, p.57.</ref> Some castles, such as [[Portchester Castle|Portchester]], were used for holding prisoners of war during the [[Napoleonic Wars]] at the end of the century and were re-equipped in case of a popular uprising during this revolutionary period.<ref name="Lowry, p.45">Lowry, p.45.</ref> In Ireland [[Dublin Castle]] was rebuilt following a fire and reaffirmed as the centre of British administrative and military power.<ref>Bartlett, p.179, 249.</ref>
Many castles remained in use as county gaols, run by gaolers as effectively private businesses; frequently this involved the gatehouse being maintained as the main prison building, as at [[Cambridge Castle|Cambridge]], [[Bridgnorth Castle|Bridgnorth]], [[Lancaster Castle|Lancaster]], [[The Castle, Newcastle|Newcastle]] and [[St Briavels Castle|St Briavels]].<ref>Pounds (1994), p.100; Harding, Hines, Ireland and Rawlings, p.114; Curnow and Johnson, p. 95.</ref> During the 1770s the prison reformer [[John Howard (prison reformer)|John Howard]] conducted his famous survey of prisons and gaols, culminating in his 1777 work ''The State of the Prisons''.<ref name="Harding, Hines p.114">Harding, Hines, Ireland and Rawlings, p.114.</ref> This documented the poor quality of these castle facilities; prisoners in [[Norwich Castle]] lived in a dungeon, with the floor frequently covered by an inch of water; [[Oxford Castle|Oxford]] was "close and offensive"; [[Worcester Castle|Worcester]] was so subject to [[Typhus|gaol-fever]] that the castle surgeon would not enter the prison; [[Gloucester Castle|Gloucester]] was "wretched in the extreme".<ref>Brown (1823), pp.125, 128, 281, 419.</ref> Howard's work caused a shift in public opinion against the use of these older castle facilities as gaols.<ref name="Harding, Hines p.114"/>
===Social and cultural use=== [[File:Old Wardour Castle 56.JPG|thumb|[[Wardour Castle]] in England, preserved in the 18th century as a fashionable ruin]] By the middle of the century medieval ruined castles had become fashionable once again. They were considered an interesting counterpoint to the now conventional Palladian classical architecture, and a way of giving a degree of medieval allure to their new owners.<ref>Gerrard, p.16; Creighton (2005), p.85.</ref> Historian Oliver Creighton suggests that the ideal image of a castle by the 1750s included "broken, soft silhouettes and [a] decayed, rough appearance".<ref name=Creighton2005P85>Creighton (2005), p.85.</ref> In some cases the countryside surrounding existing castles was remodelled to highlight the ruins, as at [[Castle Howard|Henderskelfe Castle]], or at [[Lancelot "Capability" Brown|"Capability" Brown]]'s reworking of [[Wardour Castle]].<ref name=Creighton2005P85/> Alternatively, ruins might be repaired and reinforced to present a more suitable appearance, as at [[Harewood Castle]].<ref name=Creighton2005P85/> In other cases mottes, such as that at [[Groby Castle]], were reused as the bases for dramatic [[Folly|follies]], or alternatively entirely new castle follies could be created; either from scratch or by reusing original stonework, as occurred during the building of [[Conygar Tower]] for which various parts of [[Dunster Castle]] were cannibalised.<ref>Gerrard, p.16; Creighton (2005), pp.85–6.</ref>
At the same time castles were becoming tourist attractions for the first time. By the 1740s Windsor Castle had become an early tourist attraction; wealthier visitors who could afford to pay the castle keeper could enter, see curiosities such as the castle's [[narwhal]] horn, and by the 1750s buy the first guidebooks.<ref>Tite, p.110; Robinson, p.60.</ref> The first guidebook to Kenilworth Castle followed in 1777 with many later editions following in the coming decades.<ref>Morris, p.51.</ref> By the 1780s and 1790s visitors were beginning to progress as far as [[Chepstow Castle|Chepstow]], where an attractive female guide escorted tourists around the ruins as part of the popular Wye Tour.<ref>Turner (2006), p.25; Andrews, p.89.</ref> In Scotland [[Blair Castle]] became a popular attraction on account of its landscaped gardens, as did [[Stirling Castle]] with its romantic connections.<ref>Grenier, pp.19, 152.</ref> [[Caernarfon Castle|Caernarfon]] in North Wales appealed to many visitors, especially artists.<ref>Andrews, p.131.</ref> Irish castles proved less popular, partially because contemporary tourists regarded the country as being somewhat backward and the ruins therefore failed to provide the necessary romantic contrast with modern life.<ref name=Williams2008P37>Williams (2008), p.37.</ref>
The appreciation of castles developed as the century progressed. During the 1770s and 1780s the concept of the [[picturesque]] ruin was popularised by the English clergyman [[William Gilpin (clergyman)|William Gilpin]]. Gilpin published several works on his journeys through Britain, expounding the concept of the "correctly picturesque" landscape.<ref>Malgrave, p. 60.</ref> Such a landscape, Gilpin argued, usually required a building such as a castle or other ruin to add "consequence" to the natural picture.<ref>Andrews, p.90.</ref> Paintings in this style usually portrayed castles as indistinct, faintly coloured objects in the distance; in writing, the picturesque account eschewed detail in favour of bold first impressions on the sense.<ref>Andrews, pp.78–9.</ref> The ruins of [[Goodrich Castle|Goodrich]] particularly appealed to Gilpin and his followers; [[Conwy Castle|Conwy]] was, however, too well preserved and uninteresting.<ref>Fielding, p.62; Andrews, p.125.</ref> By contrast the artistic work of antiquarians [[James Bentham]] and [[James Essex]] at the end of the century, while stopping short of being genuine archaeology, was detailed and precise enough to provide a substantial base of architectural fine detail on medieval castle features and enabled the work of architects such as Wyatt.<ref>Gerrard, p.29.</ref>
==19th century==
===Military and governmental use=== [[Image:Carrickfergus Castle2.jpg|thumb|[[Carrickfergus Castle]] in Ireland, retrofitted with gunports for [[coastal defence and fortification|coastal defence]] in the early 19th century]] The military utility of the remaining castles in Britain and Ireland continued to diminish. Some castles became [[regimental depot]]s, including [[Carlisle Castle]] and [[Chester Castle]].<ref name="Lowry, p.45"/> [[Carrickfergus Castle]] was re-equipped with gunports in order to provide coastal defences at the end of the Napoleonic period.<ref>Lowry, p.39.</ref> Political instability was a major issue during the early 19th century and the popularity of the [[Chartism|Chartist movement]] led to proposals to refortify the Tower of London in the event of civil unrest.<ref>Impey and Parnell, p.81.</ref> In Ireland [[Dublin Castle]] played an increasing role in Ireland as [[Fenian]] pressures for independence grew during the century.<ref>Ref needed.</ref>
The operation of local prisons in locations such as castles had been criticised, since John Howard's work in the 1770s, and pressure for reform continued to grow in the 1850s and 1860s.<ref>Wiener, p.108.</ref> [[Debtors' Act of 1869|Reform of the legislation surrounding bankruptcy and debt]] in 1869 largely removed the threat of imprisonment for unpaid debts, and in the process eliminated the purpose of the [[debtor's prison]]s in castles such as [[St Briavels Castle|St Briavels]].<ref>Rajak, p.14.</ref> Efforts were made to regularise conditions in local prisons but without much success, and these failures led to [[Prison Act 1877|prison reform in 1877]] which nationalised British prisons, including prisons at castles like [[York Castle|York]].<ref>Wiener, p.108; Cooper, p.196; Fox, pp.47–8.</ref> Compensation was paid to the former owners, although in cases such as York where the facilities were considered so poor as to require complete reconstruction, this payment was denied.<ref>McConville, p.505.</ref> In the short term this led to a 39% reduction in the number of prisons in England, including some famous castle prisons such as [[Norwich Castle|Norwich]]; over the coming years, centralisation and changes in prison design led to the closure of most remaining castle prisons.<ref>Bailey, p.80; McConville, pp.194, 197.</ref>
===Social and cultural use=== [[Image:Edinburgh Castle from Grass Market.jpg|thumb|right|[[Edinburgh Castle]] in Scotland in the middle of the 19th century, already a popular tourist location by the Victorian period]] Many castles saw increased visitors by tourists, helped by better transport links and the growth of the railways. The armouries at the [[Tower of London]] opened for tourists in 1828 with 40,000 visitors in their first year; by 1858 the numbers had grown to over 100,000 a year.<ref>Gerrard, p.31.</ref> Attractions such as [[Warwick Castle]] received 6,000 visitors during 1825 to 1826, many of them travelling from the growing industrial towns in the nearby Midlands, while Victorian tourists recorded being charged six-pence to wander around the ruins of [[Goodrich Castle]].<ref>Goodrich, p.523; Hassard, p. 145; Gerrard, p.31.</ref> The spread of the railway system across Wales and the Marches strongly influenced the flow of tourists to the region's castles.<ref>Bruce, p.104.</ref> In Scotland tourist tours became increasingly popular during the 19th century, usually starting at Edinburgh complete with [[Edinburgh Castle]], and then spending up to two weeks further north, taking advantage of the expanding rail and steamer network.<ref>Grenier, pp.69–70.</ref> [[Blair Castle]] remained popular, but additional castles joined the circuit – [[Cawdor Castle]] became popular once the railway line reached north to [[Fort William, Scotland|Fort William]].<ref>Grenier, p.73.</ref>
Purchasing and reading guidebooks became an increasingly important part of visiting castles; by the 1820s visitors could buy an early [[guidebook]] at Goodrich outlining the castle's history, the first guidebook to the Tower of London was published in 1841 and Scottish castle guidebooks became well known for providing long historical accounts of their sites, often drawing on the plots of Romantic novels for the details.<ref>Grenier, p.152; Jones, p.290</ref> Indeed, Sir [[Walter Scott]]'s historical novels ''[[Ivanhoe]]'' and ''[[Kenilworth (novel)|Kenilworth]]'' helped to establish the popular Victorian image of a Gothic medieval castle.<ref>Gerrard, p.30.</ref> Scott's novels set in Scotland also popularised several northern castles, including [[Tantallon Castle|Tantallon]] which was featured in ''[[Marmion (poem)|Marmion]]''.<ref>Grenier, p.82.</ref> Histories of Ireland began to stress the role of castles in the rise of Protestantism and "British values" in Ireland, although tourism remained limited.<ref name=Williams2008P37/>
[[Image:Penrhyn Castle.jpg|thumb|left|[[Penrhyn Castle]] in Wales, an early 19th-century recreation of a Norman castle]] One response to this popularity was in commissioning the construction of replica castles.<ref name=GerrardP32>Gerrard, p.32.</ref> These were particularly popular at beginning of the 19th century, and again later in the Victorian period.<ref name=GerrardP32/> Design manuals were published offering details of how to recreate the appearance of an original Gothic castles in a new build, leading to a flurry of work, such as [[Eastnor Castle|Eastnor]] in 1815, the fake [[Norman architecture|Norman]] castle of [[Penrhyn Castle|Penrhyn]] between 1827 and 1837 and the imitation [[Edward I of England|Edwardian]] castle of [[Goodrich Court]] in 1828.<ref>Gerrard, p.32; Harris, p.123.</ref> The later Victorians built the Welsh [[Castell Coch]] in the 1880s as a fantasy Gothic construction and the last such replica, [[Castle Drogo]], was built as late as 1911.<ref>Creighton and Higham, pp.63–5.</ref>
Another response was to improve existing castles, bringing their often chaotic historic features into line with a more integrated architectural aesthetic in a style often termed [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic Revivalism]].<ref name=JonesP4>Jones, p.4.</ref> There were numerous attempts to restore or rebuild castles so as to produce a consistently Gothic style, informed by genuine medieval details, a movement in which the architect [[Anthony Salvin]] was particularly prominent – as illustrated by his reworking of [[Alnwick Castle|Alnwick]] and much of [[Windsor Castle]].<ref name=JonesP4/> A similar trend can be seen at [[Rothesay Castle|Rothesay]] where [[William Burges]] renovated the older castle to produce a more "authentic" design, heavily influenced by the work of the French architect [[Eugène Viollet-le-Duc]].<ref name=GerrardP32/> North of the border this resulted in the distinctive style of [[Scots Baronial Style architecture]], which took French and traditional medieval Scottish features and reinvented them in a baroque style.<ref>Whyte and Whyte, pp.98–9.</ref> The style also proved popular in Ireland with [[George Fowler Jones|George Jones]]' [[Oliver Castle]] in the 1850s, for example, forming a good example of the fashion.<ref>O'Dwyer, p.26.</ref> As with Gothic Revivalism, Scots Baronial architects frequently "improved" existing castles: [[Floors Castle]] was transformed in 1838 by [[William Henry Playfair|William Playfair]] who added grand turrets and cupolas.<ref name=WestP116>West, p.116.</ref> In a similar way the 16th-century tower house of [[Lauriston Castle]] was turned into the Victorian ideal of a "rambling medieval house".<ref name=WestP116/> The style spread south and the famous architect [[Edward Blore]] added a Scots Baronial touch to his work at Windsor.<ref>Robinson, p.121.</ref>
With this pace of change concerns had begun to grow by the middle of the century about the threat to medieval buildings in Britain, and in 1877 [[William Morris]] established the [[Society for the Protection of Ancient Buildings]].<ref name="Mynors, p.8">Mynors, p.8.</ref> One result of public pressure was the passing of the [[Ancient Monuments Protection Act 1882]], but the provisions of the act focused on unoccupied prehistoric structures and medieval buildings such as castles were exempted from it leaving no legal protection.<ref>Gerrard, p.30; Mynors, p.8.</ref>
==20th–21st century==
===1900–1945=== [[Image:Beaumaris Castle - geograph.org.uk - 28577.jpg|thumb|[[Beaumaris Castle]] in Wales, showing its restored appearance following work in the 1920s]]
During the first half of the century several castles were maintained, or brought back into military use. During the [[Irish War of Independence]] [[Dublin Castle]] remained the centre of the British administration, military and intelligence operations in Ireland until the transfer of power and the castle to the [[Irish Free State]] in 1922.<ref>Cottrell, pp.16–20.</ref> During the Second World War the [[Tower of London]] was used to hold and execute suspected spies, and was used to briefly detain [[Rudolf Hess]], [[Adolf Hitler]]'s deputy, in 1941.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.hrp.org.uk/Resources/Executions%20at%20the%20Tower.pdf |title=Executions at The Tower Of London |format=PDF |publisher=[[Historic Royal Palaces]] |accessdate=31 July 2010}}; I & P, p.123.</ref> [[Edinburgh Castle]] was used as a prisoner of war facility, while [[Windsor Castle]] was stripped of more delicate royal treasures and used to guard the [[British Royal Family|British royal family]] from the dangers of [[the Blitz]].<ref>Tabraham (2004), p.63; Shawcross, p.487.</ref> Some coastal castles were used to support naval operations: [[Dover Castle]]'s medieval fortifications used as basis for defences across the [[Dover Strait]]; [[Pitreavie Castle]] in Scotland was used to support the Royal Navy; and [[Carrickfergus Castle]] in Ireland was used as a coastal defence base.<ref>Lowry, p.45; Creighton and Higham, p.62; Reid, pp.56–7.</ref> Some castles, such as [[Cambridge Castle|Cambridge]] and [[Pevensey Castle|Pevensey]], were brought into local defence plans in case of a German invasion.<ref>Lowry, p.23; Creighton and Higham, p.62.</ref> A handful of these castles retained a military role after the war; Dover was used as a [[Fallout shelter|nuclear war command centre]] into the 1950s, while Pitreavie was used by NATO until the turn of the 21st century.<ref>Lowry, p.45; Creighton and Higham, p.62; Reid, p.57.</ref>
The strong cultural interest in British castles persisted in the 20th century. In some cases this had destructive consequences as wealthy collectors bought and removed architectural features and other historical artefacts from castles for their own collections, a practice that produced significant official concern.<ref>Gerrard, p.76.</ref> Some of the more significant cases included [[St Donat's Castle]], bought by [[William Randolph Hearst]] in 1925 and then decorated with numerous medieval buildings removed from their original sites around Britain, and the case of [[Hornby Castle, Yorkshire|Hornby]], where many parts of the castle were sold off and sent to buyers in the United States.<ref>Gerrard, pp.76–7.</ref> Partially as a result of these events, increasing legal powers were introduced to protect castles – acts of parliament in [[Ancient Monuments Act (1900)|1900]] and [[Ancient Monuments Protection Act (1910)|1910]] widened the terms of the earlier legislation on national monuments to allow the inclusion of castles.<ref name="Mynors, p.8"/> An [[Ancient Monuments Act (1913)|act of Parliament in 1913]] introduced preservation orders for the first time and these powers were extended in [[Ancient Monuments Act 1931|1931]].<ref>Gerrard, p.77; Mynors, p.9.</ref> Similarly, after the end of the [[Irish Civil War]], the new Irish state took early action to extend and strengthen the previous British legislation to protect Irish national monuments.<ref>Zuelow, p.140.</ref>
Around the beginning of the century there were a number of major restoration projects on British castles. Before the outbreak of the [[First World War]] work was undertaken at [[Chepstow Castle|Chepstow]], [[Bodiam Castle|Bodiam]], [[Caernarfon Castle|Caernarfon]] and [[Tattershall Castle|Tattershal]]; after the end of the war various major state funded restoration projects occurred in the 1920s with [[Pembroke Castle|Pembroke]], [[Caerphilly Castle|Caerphilly]] and [[Goodrich Castle|Goodrich]] amongst the largest of these.<ref>Gerrard, p.66; Creighton and Higham, p.64; Turner (2006) p.25.</ref> This work typically centred on cutting back the vegetation encroaching on castle ruins, especially ivy, and removing damaged or unstable stonework; castles such as [[Beaumaris Castle|Beaumaris]] saw their moats cleaned and reflooded.<ref>Creighton and Higham, p.64; Gerrard, p.66.</ref> Some castles such as [[Eilean Donan]] in Scotland were substantially rebuilt in the inter-war years. The early UK film industry took an interest in castles as potential sets, starting with [[Ivanhoe (1913 U.S. film)|Ivanhoe]] filmed at [[Chepstow Castle]] in 1913 and starring US leading actor [[King Baggot]].<ref>Creighton and Higham, pp.65–6; Turner (2006), pp.25–6.</ref>
===1945–21st century=== [[Image:Yard2.jpg|thumb|[[Durham Castle]] in England, declared a UNESCO [[World Heritage Site]] in the 1980s]] After the Second World War picturesque ruins of castles became unfashionable. The conservation preference was to restore castles so as to produce what Oliver Creighton and Robert Higham have described as a "meticulously cared for fabric, neat lawns and [a] highly regulated, visitor-friendly environment", although the reconstruction or reproduction of the original appearance of castles was discouraged.<ref name="Creighton and Higham, p.65">Creighton and Higham, p.65.</ref> As a result, the stonework and walls of today's castles, used as tourist attractions, are usually in much better condition than would have been the case in the medieval period.<ref>Pounds (1994), p.126.</ref> Preserving the broader landscapes of the past also rose in importance, reflected in the decision by the UNESCO [[World Heritage Site]] programme to internationally recognise several British castles including [[Beaumaris Castle|Beaumaris]], [[Caernarfon Castle|Caernarfon]], [[Conwy Castle|Conwy]], [[Harlech Castle|Harlech]], [[Durham Castle|Durham]] and the [[Tower of London]] as deserving of special international cultural significance in the 1980s.<ref>Creighton and Higham, p.64.</ref>
The single largest group of English castles are now those owned by [[English Heritage]], created out of the former [[Ministry of Works (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Works]] [[National Heritage Act 1983|in 1983]].<ref>Pettifer (2002), p.xxi; Delafons, pp.137–140.</ref> The [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] increasingly acquired castle properties in England in the 1950s, and is the second largest single owner, followed by the various English local authorities and finally a small number of private owners.<ref>Pettifer (2002), p.xxi.</ref> Royal castles such as the Tower of London and Windsor are owned by the Occupied Royal Palaces Estate on behalf of the nation.<ref name=HouseOfCommonsP3>House of Commons Public Accounts Committee, p.3.</ref> Similar organisations exist in Scotland, where the [[National Trust for Scotland]] was established 1931, and in Ireland, where [[An Taisce]] was created in 1948 to working alongside the Irish Ministry of Works to maintain castles and other sites.<ref>Zuelow, pp.142, 205.</ref> Some new organisations have emerged in recent years to manage castles, such as the [[Landmark Trust]] and the Irish Landmark Trust, which have restored a number of castles in Britain and Ireland over the last few decades.
Castles remain highly popular attractions: in 2009 nearly 2.4 million people visited the Tower of London, 1.2 million visited [[Edinburgh Castle]], 559,000 visited [[Leeds Castle]] and 349,000 visited [[Dover Castle]].<ref>''[http://www.alva.org.uk/details.cfm?p=423 Visits Made in 2010 to Visitor Attractions in Membership with ALVA],'' Association of Leading Visitor Attractions. Accessed 29 February 2012.</ref> Ireland, which for many years had not exploited the tourist potential of its castle heritage, began to encourage more tourists in the 1960s and 1970s and Irish castles are now a core part of the Irish tourist industry.<ref>Zuelow, pp.142–6.</ref> British and Irish castles are today also closely linked to the international [[film industry]], with tourist visits to castles now often involving not simply a visit to an historic site, but also a visit to the location of a popular film.<ref>Ryan, p.118.</ref>
[[Image:Wigmore Castle Ruins.jpg|thumb|left|[[Wigmore Castle]] in England, preserved in an unconserved state following its acquisition by [[English Heritage]] in 1995]] The management and handling of Britain's historic castles has at times been contentious. Castles in the late 20th and early 21st century are usually considered part of the heritage industry, in which historic sites and events are commercially presented as visitor attractions.<ref>Gilmour, p.82.</ref> Some academics, such as David Lowenthal, have critiqued the way in which these histories are constantly culturally and socially reconstructed and condemned the "commercial debasement" of sites such as the Tower of London.<ref>Lowenthal (1985), p.278; Lowenthal (1996), p.101, cited Gilmour, p.83.</ref> The challenge of how to manage these historic properties has often required very practical decisions. At one end of the spectrum owners and architects have had to deal with the practical challenges of repairing smaller decaying castles used as private houses, such as that at [[Picton Castle]] where damp proved a considerable problem.<ref>Insall, p.52.</ref> At the other end of the scale [[1992 Windsor Castle fire|the fire at Windsor Castle]] in 1992 opened up a national debate about how the burnt out castle wing should be replaced, the degree to which modern designs should be introduced and who should pay the £37 million costs (£50.2 million in 2009 terms).<ref name="Measuring Worth"/><ref>Robinson, p.145; Nicolson, p.71.</ref> At [[Kenilworth Castle|Kenilworth]] the speculative and commercial reconstruction of the castle gardens in an Elizabethan style led to a vigorous academic debate over the interpretation of archaeological and historical evidence.<ref>Greene and Moore, p.298.</ref> Trends in conservation have altered and, in contrast to the prevailing post-war approach to conservation, recent work at castles such as [[Wigmore Castle|Wigmore]], acquired by English Heritage in 1995, have attempted to minimise the degree of intervention to the site.<ref name="Creighton and Higham, p.65"/>
{{wide image|2007-08-26-09095 GreatBritain Warwick.jpg|650px|Tourists at [[Warwick Castle]] in England}}
==Historiography== [[Image:Its down here somewhere - geograph.org.uk - 1426035.jpg|thumb|Archaeological investigations in 2009 attempt to identify the exact location of [[Ampthill|Ampthill Castle]]]] The earliest histories of British and Irish castles were recorded, albeit in a somewhat fragmented fashion, by [[John Leland (antiquary)|John Leland]] in the 16th century and, by the 19th century, historical analysis of castles had become popular.<ref>Creighton and Higham, p.8.</ref> Victorian historians such as [[G. T. Clark|George Clark]] and John Parker concluded that British castles had been built for the purposes of military defence, but believed that their history was pre-Conquest – concluding that the [[motte and bailey|mottes]] across the countryside had been built by either the [[Ancient Rome|Romans]] or [[Celts]].<ref>Liddiard (2005), p.3; Creighton and Highan, p.8; Clark (1884); Parker (1882).</ref>
The study of castles by historians and archaeologists developed considerably during the 20th century. The early-20th-century historian and archaeologist [[Ella Sophia Armitage|Ella Armitage]] published a ground-breaking book in 1912, arguing convincingly that British castles were in fact a Norman introduction, while historian Alexander Thompson also published in the same year, charting the course of the military development of English castles through the Middle Ages.<ref>Liddiard (2005), p.3; Armitage (1912); Thompson (1912).</ref> The [[Victoria County History]] of England began to document the country's castles on an unprecedented scale, providing an additional resource for historical analysis.<ref>Gerrard, p.78.</ref>
After the Second World War the historical analysis of British castles was dominated by [[A. J. Taylor|Arnold Taylor]], R. Allen Brown and D. J. Cathcart King.<ref>Liddiard (2005), p.5.</ref> These academics made use of a growing amount of archaeological evidence, as the 1940s saw an increasing number of excavations of motte and bailey castles, and the number of castle excavations as a whole went on to double during the 1960s.<ref>Gerrard, p.109.</ref> With an increasing number of castle sites under threat in urban areas, a public scandal in 1972 surrounding the development of the [[Baynard's Castle]] site in London contributed to reforms and a re-prioritisation of funding for [[rescue archaeology]].<ref>Gerrard, p.134.</ref> Despite this the number of castle excavations fell between 1974 and 1984, with the archaeological work focusing on conducting excavations on a greater number of small-scale, but fewer large-scale sites.<ref name=GerrardP146>Gerrard, p.146.</ref> The study of British castles remained primarily focused on analysing their military role, however, drawing on the evolutionary model of improvements suggested by Thompson earlier in the century.<ref>Liddiard (2005), pp.5–6.</ref>
In the 1990s a wide-reaching reassessment of the interpretation of British castles took place. A vigorous academic discussion over the history and meanings behind [[Bodiam Castle]] began a debate, which concluded that many features of castles previously seen as primarily military in nature were in fact constructed for reasons of status and political power.<ref>Liddiard (2005), pp.7–11.</ref> As historian Robert Liddiard has described it, the older paradigm of "Norman militarism" as the driving force behind the formation of Britain's castles was replaced by a model of "peaceable power".<ref>Liddiard (2003b), p.9.</ref> The next twenty years was characterised by an increasing number of major publications on castle studies, examining the social and political aspects of the fortifications, as well as their role in the historical landscape.<ref name=Liddiard2005PP10>Liddiard (2005), pp.10–11.</ref> Although not unchallenged, this "revisionist" perspective remains the dominant theme in the academic literature today.<ref name=Liddiard2005PP10/>
